en.intro_1: The ocean covers almost 70% of the Earth's surface...
en.intro_2: and most of it still remains unexplored.
en.intro_3: Exploring the ocean is no easy task, as it's a place brimming with as much danger as there is mystery.
en.intro_4: For those brave enough to take on this challenge, we use a special process to uncover these mysteries:
en.title: Triton's Treasure
en.subtitle: A Scientific Method Adventure
en.inventory-item_desc_conch: Your new ocean friend. Grants the ability to understand the language of the sea.
en.inventory-item_action_conch: Use this to receive a hint whenever you are stuck.
en.inventory-item_desc_sm: A diagram of the Scientific Method.
en.inventory-item_action_sm: Use this to review the Scientific Method steps.
en.desc_shell:
A large sea snail with a horn-shaped shell.
There is something mysterious about this one...
en.ch1-dialog_1-5: Yes, what are you doing here?
en.ch1-dialog_1-7: Yes, I can talk...it's really not a big deal. Now answer me.
en.ch1-dialog_2-1: We are ocean explorers. Our job is to venture into the unknown and make discoveries using the Scientific Method.
en.ch1-dialog_sm-1: It's a process we use to make sense about the world around us. It involves:
en.ch1-dialog_sm-7: Then finally, coming up with a conclusion.
en.ch1-dialog_sm-9: Yes, but this process allows us to have experiments that can be repeated and verified by others.
en.ch1-dialog_sm-10: If many come to the same conclusion, then we can be more confident that it's true.
en.ch1-dialog_3-1: The ocean is a magical place full of mysteries and wonders.
en.ch1-dialog_3-2: By making new discoveries and sharing them with others, maybe we can understand it better.
en.ch1-dialog_3-3: That way, we'll not only learn how to use its resources more wisely, but also how to protect it.
en.ch1-dialog_4-1: ...very well. Can I come too? I want to help.
en.ch1-dialog_4-2: Sure, you can join our exploration team.
en.ch1-dialog_4-4: The deeper we go, the more unknown and dangerous things we may find.
en.ch2-question: What are the first few steps of the Scientific Method?
en.ch2-question_option-1: Observe the natural world, analyse the data, then form a hypothesis
en.ch2-question_option-1-dialog: Observing the natural world first is correct, but we need to form a hypothesis and conduct an experiment before we have any data to analyze.
en.ch2-question_option-2: Ask a scientific question, conduct an experiment, then come up with a conclusion
en.ch2-question_option-2-dialog: The order is correct, but you’re missing too many steps in between.
en.ch2-question_option-3: Observe the natural world, ask a scientific question, then form a hypothesis
en.ch2-dialog_1-1: Let's try to explore and make some observations about this place.
en.ch2-dialog_1-2: Step 1, observe the natural world right?
en.ch2-info_kelp-1: This giant kelp has almost grown to the surface!
en.ch2-info_kelp-2: It seems to really enjoy the sunlight.
en.ch2-info_foliage-1: Much less foliage growing here than above.
en.ch2-info_color-1: The color of the water is a bit different here.
en.ch2-info_color-2: The color is getting much darker now.
